title: Not the Same SMS PopUp
comment: Going to 4.4 changes some aspects of the app.  First, you no longer have the popup display in the lock screen, which was a convenient way to not only read the SMS, but also respond to it via the Quick Reply.  With 4.4 you only see the icon in the status bar indicating your have a text (provided you turned off the Notification feature with the SMS App).  Second, replying via the popup no longer marks the message as read (which is written in the description).  These two features made a difference.  Perhaps the developer will work on them, which would bring it back from a 3 star to a 5.

title: Simple yet powerful
comment: My favorite feature is the ability to define, at the level of milliseconds, any arbitrary vibration pattern for messages. It can take a little experimentation, but the way this app handles custom vibration patterns (entered as a string of off/on durations) allows for precise timing -- which you can use to set up distinctive musical (rhythmic) notifications that are more subtle than using a song itself as a ringtone.   I don't use many of the app's other features, but they look similarly elegant.

title: Great App, But One Minor Flaw
comment: This is a great app.  Lightweight, clean, and a piece of cake to configure.  The only thing that really bugs me is when you tap the "Inbox" button on the Quick Reply screen.  Instead of it taking you into that particular conversation, it will take you into the last conversation that you were in in the stock messaging app.  I am not sure if this is a bug in the SMS Popup app or the stock messaging app.  I will continue to use the app as this is just a minor annoyance to me, but others should be careful that they don't send a message to the wrong person thinking they were taken into the desired conversation.  I will give it three stars for now and a full 5 upon this being resolved.

title: Love it, almost perfect
comment: This is a great app that I have used since I owned the G1.  I love it and I can't recommend it more to anyone.  The only problem is that every single one of my in-laws use iPhones and they constantly send messages to large groups which Android now supports, but act a little weird in SMS Popup.  When a message comes from a person sent to many, SMS Popup won't show the contents and have a simple message saying it is a MMS.  If you click "Reply" it will take you the the thread of that individual that sent you the message, and not the thread of the group that it was sent from/to.  Although I have been VERY apposed to mass SMS conversations between 10+ people, I have given in to the inevitability that I am on my own little island protesting by myself.  I would love to see SMS Popup support showing text from MMS mass messages, and have "Reply" go to the correct thread.  ********* PROS: Multiple messages supported by sliding.   Reading messages aloud with one click (Great for the car).   Clean interface.    ********* CONS: No MMS support for showing text of message.   No mass SMS (sent as MMS) support.

title: Why this isn't built-in, I don't know.
comment: It baffles my mind why this isn't already baked-in to Android. As it stands, this is by far the best option if you want to stick with stock messaging. Worked perfectly on my old Thunderbolt and on my current Galaxy Nexus (just pay attention to the instructions and turn off stock notifications).   Would be nice if maybe there were theme options, but that is nitpicking. More customization is always nice. There's always room for improvement, but from a functionality perspective, I consider this an essential app. And the fact that Adam K has NO ads and NO pestering for you to donate really speaks to his character. That's why it gets 5 stars. This guy really needs to be paid for this.

title: Good, but a few annoying issues
comment: 1) Seems laggy sometimes. Not sure why this is since it's such a simple app. 2) When Text Messaging is open there is no reason why the pop ups should still appear - I'm already looking at my messages.  Should be smart enough to realize when Text Messaging is being used and suppress the popup. 3) If I get 20 new text messages, that's 20 times I have to click "Close".  There should be an X in the corner that will close all popups at once, rather than just 1 at a time. 4) "Vibrate Off" doesn't work on my Razr Maxx unless I set a custom Vibration pattern of "0,0"  If these issues were fixed, the stock Text Messaging app+ SMS Popup would be a perfect texting combination.

title: Iphone switchers, try this app!
comment: The built-in app for iphones has options for missed text alerts, and it also shows the text on the locked screen.  I love my new Android phone, but this is one of the things I missed most.  Maybe this has been addressed in later versions of Android, but for folks like me using an older version, this app fixes that shortcoming.  It pops up a window showing the text, and it gives you 3 buttons that you can customize on how to proceed (inbox, reply, delete, quick reply, etc.)  I highly recommend it, at least for my particular phone: LG Optimus Elite using Gingerbread (2.3.7).

title: Great, but one little problem..
comment: Great app, but there is a huge security exploit that needs to be fixed.  I don't know if this is just my phone or if it's this way for all phones, so if yo're reading this you should definitely check it out for yourself if you value your phone's security.  On my Galaxy S2 Skyrocket (running Gingerbread), if I have it set to "screen on for popup" and I receive a message while my phone is locked and I don't execute any action by tapping one of the buttons it will go back to sleep, but upon waking the phone up it goes to the "slide to unlock" screen instead of the lock screen!  This could allow a third party to bypass the lock screen and get into my phone - all it would take is a text message to a stolen phone, and whoever stole it could have access to my information if they didn't attempt to close the popup or reply.  I'm not always in situations where I can check my messages immediately, so I can't have my phone going unlocked every time I get a new message that I can't immediately check.  Other than that though, pretty great app!  I will just have to disable this option until this can (hopefully) be fixed, because otherwise I like that feature.

title: Failing to get notifications
comment: Lately I've been failing to get any further text message notifications when I don't cancel/respond to a prior one. Until I take any action regarding that initial text message, I'll receive absolutely no notification of any kind (sound, icons, vibration, etc) that there I have other new text messages waiting. This has caused quite a few muddle-ups with people trying to contact me and it's extremely frustrating when it occurs. I've tested this on both my Evo 3d and my wife's Epic 4g and it's happened on both, and quite replicable.   This app is otherwise quite handy, but until this bug gets addressed I'll need to keep it uninstalled to ensure all messages sent to me get through.

title: Completely Perfect!  Exactly my Galaxy Nexus Needs
comment: Came from iPhone and missed my notifications, tried 3 different apps but all lacked something.  This app does EXACTLY what I want and took about 2 minutes to configure.  Only free app so far that I can properly display pop up from lock screen WITH the full message (or without if u prefer) and without buttons I have to worry about while in my pocket. LOVE that I can make custom notifications for specific contacts, LOVE that I can create the exact custom vibrate pattern I want as I often miss texts while my phone is in my pocket. LOVE that I can turn OFF the pop up when I'm already texting someone back (that was super annoying in other apps). Preset response option is great so I can quickly send out things like "thanks" and "ok" that I say all the time. I love that I can still use my voice to dictate as well. Really you've added everything I needed and it works flawlessly on my Galaxy Nexus running Android 4 ICS and all for FREE. Thanks so much. I will be donating, you've managed to make a better app than 2 of the paid apps I've seen.
I love it!
